thig13.2:1.1: This is Rohinī's father speaking. (Day and night you speak about contemplatives,)
thig13.2:11.2: 'manta' can mean either 'mantra' or 'advice/counseling'. So this might be "giving advice, unconceited" or "giving counsel without conceit" or some such.
thig13.2:13.3: "Seeking complete perfection" (pariniṭṭhita lit means "completely finished" and may refer to awakening - as in, one who is 'completely finished' with saṁsāra, 'completely finished' with the spiritual life)
thig13.2:16.4: 'tibbagāravā'  - 'tibbā' means 'sharp' or 'extreme', 'gāravā' means 'reverence'. So I think 'tibbagāravā' means 'extreme reverence'. the word 'devout' implies devotion, which I think is a bit different.
